Violation_Type: Failure to meet residency requirement for citizenship
Legal_Issue: Does Kehua Yu meet the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Yu spent only 17 days in Canada initially
Was absent for 939 days during the relevant period
Had a room at her uncle's and maintained healthcare coverage
Remedy_Requested: Reversal of Citizenship Court’s decision granting citizenship
Court_Ruling: Yu did not meet the residency requirement due to lack of initial establishment of residency
Defendant_Behavior: Applied for citizenship while primarily residing in the U.S. for schooling
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to reside in Canada for at least three years immediately preceding application
Legal_Standard: Residency requires settling into an ordinary mode of living with social relations and interests
Assessment_Factor: Duration of stay, social ties, intent to reside
Procedural_Issue: Minister appealed Citizenship Court’s grant of citizenship
Evidence_Used: Travel records, ties to Canada (room, healthcare)
Application_Basis: Physical presence and establishment of residential ties
Evidence_Assessed: Limited physical presence outweighed minimal Canadian ties
Relief_Sought: Denial of citizenship application until residency is fulfilled
Governing_Rule: Residency must be established before absences for temporary purposes
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of initial residency establishment
Outcome: Appeal allowed; citizenship revoked pending compliance
Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper citizenship grant undermining immigration integrity
Cause_Description: Yu applied for citizenship despite prolonged absence and minimal presence in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Factual review based on documented stays and connections
Evidence_Issues: Lack of evidence showing integration into Canadian community
Evidence_Assessment: Ties to Canada were insufficient to establish residency
Decision_Rationale: Short initial stay and extended absence prevented establishment of residency
Country_of_Origin: China (implied by name and U.S. schooling context)
Evidentiary_Issues: Minimal documentation of actual residence and integration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective test for residency based on settled mode of living
